content:
Having the conversation at your mom's house can be a good idea, as it's a familiar and comfortable setting for both of you. However, the timing is crucial. I would recommend having the conversation after dinner, when you're both more relaxed and have some one-on-one time. Here's why:

**Dinner can be a busy and distracting time**: During dinner, there may be a lot of conversation, food being passed around, and other distractions. This can make it difficult to have a focused and meaningful conversation about a sensitive topic like your argument.

**After dinner, you'll have more privacy and quiet time**: Once dinner is over, you can excuse yourselves and find a quiet spot to talk. This will give you both a chance to focus on the conversation without interruptions or distractions.

**You'll be more relaxed and in a better mindset**: After dinner, you'll have had a chance to unwind and relax a bit. This can help you both approach the conversation with a clearer head and a more open mindset.

**You can take your time and have a more in-depth conversation**: Without the time pressure of finishing dinner or worrying about others listening in, you can take your time to discuss the issue at hand and explore each other's perspectives more thoroughly.

Consider suggesting a walk, grabbing a cup of coffee or tea, or finding a cozy spot in the living room to chat after dinner. This will give you both a chance to have a more relaxed and focused conversation.

Remember to approach the conversation with an open mind, empathy, and a willingness to listen to your sister's perspective. Good luck, and I hope the conversation goes well!
